Furthermore, how can it be known that, as for the dependent nature, the imagined nature appears but does not correspond to its essence?

Because there is contradiction in the absence of the essence of the cognition prior to the name, because there is contradiction in the multiplicity of essences due to the multiplicity of names, and because there is contradiction in the mixture of essences due to the indeterminacy of names.
Here there are two verses:
Because of the absence of cognition prior to the name, the multiplicity of names, and indeterminacy,
There is contradiction in the establishment of the correspondence of essence, multiplicity of essences, and mixture of essences.
Dharmas are nonexistent yet can be obtained, uncontaminated yet have purity,
One should know they are like illusions and so forth, and also similar to space.
The commentary says:
Although the imagined aspect of the dependent nature appears and can be obtained, it does not correspond to its essence.
In order to illustrate this meaning, it is said that the cognition before the name contradicts the essence of the name.
If the dependent and the imagined have the same characteristic, then the cognition of the object should occur without depending on the name.
Just as when grasping the existence of a pot, if one is apart from the name of the pot, there is no cognition of the pot in regard to the meaning of the pot.
If this name of the pot and that meaning of the pot have the same characteristic, then the cognition of the pot should occur;
but because they do not have the same characteristic, it does not occur.

By this, if the name and meaning have the same essence, then it becomes contradictory. Here, the name is established as the dependent and the meaning as the imagined, because the dependent is imagined by the power of the name.
Moreover, there are many names for one meaning. If the name and meaning have the same characteristic, then the meaning should be like the name and also have many kinds.
If so, then this meaning should become multiple entities. One meaning and multiple entities then become contradictory.
Therefore, if the two natures have the same characteristic, it becomes the second fault of contradiction.
Moreover, names are indeterminate, because the one sound go occurs with nine meanings.
If one grasps that names and meanings have the same characteristic, then many meanings contradicting each other should have the same essence, which becomes the third fault of contradiction.
Because one grasps that the meanings of cow, etc. are not of the same characteristic, but of the same nature, the first verse reiterates this meaning.
Among them, established shows that the other-dependent and the imagined are not established as having the same meaning.
Dharmas are nonexistent yet can be obtained, etc. This one verse uses the analogy of illusions, etc. to enlighten the disciples.
Disciples have two contradictory questions:
How can dharmas be nonexistent yet presently obtainable?
How can there be purity without defilement?
Here, two analogies explain these questions.
Like illusions, etc. is like an illusory elephant that is actually nonexistent yet can be obtained.
One should understand that the meaning here is also like this. Although it can be presently obtained, it does not really exist.
As for being like space, it is like how space, although not defiled by clouds and so forth because its nature is pure, is said to be pure when separated from them.

One should understand that dharmas are also like this. Although they are not really defiled because their nature is pure, when the adventitious defilements are extinguished and eliminated, they are said to be pure.
The treatise states:
Next, why is it that the real nature of things as they appear does not exist, yet the dependent nature is not completely nonexistent?
If this [dependent nature] did not exist, the perfected nature would also not exist.
If this [perfected nature] did not exist, then everything would be nonexistent.
If the dependent nature and the perfected nature did not exist, there would be the error of no defilement and purity.
Since defilement and purity are presently obtained, therefore everything should not be nonexistent.
Here there is a verse:
If there were no dependent arising, the perfected reality would also not exist.
If all kinds were non-existent, there would be no defilement or purity at any time.
The commentary says:
If the dependent arising is as it is obtained, it is not like this, then why is it not the case that everything is completely non-existent?
If this were non-existent, the perfected reality would also not exist.
Why is it so?
Because there is defilement and purity.
If the two were both non-existent, then all kinds would be completely non-existent.
Now, it should be shown that this is not completely non-existent, because there is the fault of denying defilement and purity.
Since defilement and purity are presently obtained, therefore these two natures are both not non-existent.
If one grasps them as non-existent, then one denies the presently existing defilement and purity, saying they do not exist.
The treatise says:
The World-Honored Buddhas in the Mahayana teach the vaipulya teachings. In those teachings, it is said:
How should one understand the nature of the imagined?
It should be known that the other approach speaks of non-existence.
How should one know the nature of dependent arising?
It should be known as being like an illusion, a mirage, a dream, an image, a light, a shadow, an echo in a valley, the moon in water, and a transformation.
How should one know the nature of perfect accomplishment?
It should be known as being the teaching of the four pure dharmas.
What are called the four pure dharmas?
First, the purity of intrinsic nature, which refers to suchness, emptiness, the ultimate reality, signlessness, the supreme truth, and the dharma realm.
Second, the purity of being free from defilements, which refers to being free from all the defilements of hindrances.
Third, the purity of attaining this path, which refers to all the factors of enlightenment, the perfections, and so forth.

Fourth, the purity of the realm that gives rise to this, which refers to the marvelous and correct teachings of the MahÄyÄna.ğŸ”½Because of the pure conditions of this Dharma teaching, it is not the nature of imagination;
Because it is the nature that flows from the purest dharma realm, it is not the nature of dependent arising.
These four dharmas comprehensively include all pure dharmas.
Here there are two verses:
Illusion and so forth are said to be production, non-existent imagined [nature] is said;
If the four purities are spoken of, that is called perfect accomplishment.
Intrinsic nature and stainless, pure path and object,
All pure dharmas are all included in the four characteristics.
The commentary says:

Intrinsic purity means that this intrinsic nature is originally pure, which is precisely the intrinsic nature of suchness, truly existing, and the common characteristics shared equally by all sentient beings;
Because of this, it is said that all dharmas have the TathÄgata-store.
Stainless purity means that suchness is far removed from the defilements of afflictions and the knowledge of objects, and precisely by means of such pure suchness, the buddhas are manifested.

As for the attainment of the purity of this path, it means that the attainment of this holy path of suchness is precisely purity, referring to the factors of enlightenment such as the establishments of mindfulness and all the perfections.
As for the arising of the purity of this object, it means the arising of the objects of cognition of the factors of enlightenment that are able to realize [enlightenment].
The arising of this object is precisely purity, thus it is called the arising of the purity of this object, referring to the twelve divisions of the teachings such as the sutras.
Why is this?
If this holy teaching were imaginary, it would be the cause of defilement.
If it were dependent arising, it would be false.
Because it is the nature that flows from the purest dharma realm, it is not false.
Since it is free from the two natures, it is thus established as the perfected nature.
Moreover, if any one of these four is spoken of in the Mahayana, it should be known as speaking of the perfected nature.
Among them, the first two are unchanging, and because they are perfected, they are called perfected.
The latter two kinds are without inversion, and because they are perfectly accomplished, they are called perfectly accomplished.
The latter verse summarizes this meaning.
Illusion and so forth are said to be produced means that dependent arising is called production here.
If in a certain place it is said that all dharmas are like an illusion, up to and including transformation, one should know that this refers to the dependent nature.

It is said that there is no imagined means that if in a certain place it is said that there is no form, up to and including that there are no all dharmas, one should know that this refers to the imagined nature.
The treatise says:
Next, why is the analogy of illusion and so forth given in the sutra for the dependent nature?
In order to remove others' false doubts about the dependent nature.
How do others have false doubts about the dependent nature?
Because others have doubts about this, thinking:
How can there be objects that actually do not exist, yet become the objects of activity?
In order to remove this doubt, the analogy of an illusion is given.
How can there be the occurrence of mind and mental factors without objects?
To remove this doubt, the analogy of a mirage is given.
How can there be the distinction of pleasant and unpleasant enjoyment without objects?
To remove this doubt, the analogy of a dream is given.
How can there be the arising of the distinction of pure and impure actions, pleasant and unpleasant results, without objects?
To remove this doubt, the analogy of a reflection is given.
How can there be the occurrence of various consciousnesses without objects?
To remove this doubt, the analogy of a shadow is given.
How can there be the occurrence of various conceptual proliferations and verbal expressions without objects?
To remove this doubt, the analogy of an echo is given.
How can there be the occurrence of the objects of concentration practice, which are real apprehensions without objects?
To remove this doubt, the analogy of the moon in the water is given.
How can bodhisattvas, without objects, think to take birth in order to accomplish the welfare and happiness of sentient beings with a non-inverted mind?
To remove this doubt, the analogy of a transformation is given.
The commentary says:
For this meaning, the analogy of illusion and so forth is given regarding the other-dependent nature. Now it will be shown.

Here, the deluded doubt refers to all doubts regarding the illusory other-dependent nature. In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of illusion and so forth is given to illustrate the other-dependent.
If there is no real object, how can it become the object?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of an illusion is given to illustrate the other-dependent.
Just as an illusory elephant, although without real meaning, becomes an object, so is the object.
Others again give rise to doubt:
If there is no object, there is nothing to be the object-condition. How do the mind and mental factors arise?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of a mirage is given to illustrate the other-dependent.

Here, the mirage is analogous to the mind and mental factors, and the water is analogous to the object. Just as a mirage, due to its flickering, gives rise to the perception of water even though there is no object,
so it is with the mind and mental factors. Due to their flickering, even though there is no object, they give rise to the perception of an object.
These foolish people have another doubt:
If there is no real object, how can the distinction between the enjoyment of what is desirable and what is not be obtained?
In order to remove this doubt, the example of a dream is given to illustrate the other-dependent nature.
Just as in a dream, although there is no real object, one still sees the distinction between the enjoyment of what is desirable and what is not, which is present and can be obtained, so is this.
Here they have another doubt:
If the meaning of pure and impure karma is really nonexistent, how can the meaning of the fruits of what is desirable and what is not arise?
In order to remove this doubt, the example of a reflection is given to illustrate the other-dependent nature.
Just as a reflection is really without meaning, and the perception of a reflection arises from the original substance, but the meaning of the reflection cannot be obtained separately,
so is this. One should know that although there is no real meaning of the fruits of what is desirable and what is not, they are still present and can be obtained.
Here they have another doubt:
If there is no real object, how can there be the arising of various consciousnesses?
In order to remove this doubt, the example of a light and its shadow is given to illustrate the other-dependent nature.
Just as one who plays with shadows can obtain various kinds of light and shadows, although many kinds of light and shadows can be obtained, the meaning of light and shadows is actually non-existent.
Consciousness is also like this. It has no meaning of various kinds, but the appearance of various kinds of meaning can be obtained.
There is further doubt about this:
If there is no meaning, how can the innumerable kinds of discursive language function?
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of an echo is given to illustrate the other-dependent nature.
Just as an echo, although without meaning, can be obtained, so too are discursive language and expressions, although without real meaning, still obtainable.
There is further doubt about this:
If there is no meaning, how can the definite mind and mental factors of the world obtain meaning?
Because it is said that the concentrated mind can know as it really is and see as it really is.
In order to eliminate this doubt, the analogy of the moon in the water is given to illustrate the other-dependent nature.
Just as the moon in the water is actually non-existent in meaning, but due to the moist, smooth, and clear nature of the water, it can be obtained.
The same is true of the mind in samÄdhi. Although the object of perception is actually nonexistent, it can be perceived.
Water is used as a metaphor for samÄdhi because it has the nature of moistening, smoothness, and clarity.
There is another doubt here:

If the meaning of sentient beings is actually nonexistent, how can the bodhisattvas who realize the truth, with wisdom as the forerunner, take on their own bodies in the various destinies in order to benefit and bring happiness to them?
In order to remove this doubt, the metaphor of magical transformation is used to illustrate dependent arising.
Just as in magical transformation there is actually no meaning, yet all things are accomplished by the power of the magician, and the meaning of the magical transformation cannot be obtained.

One should know that this is also so here. Although the meaning of one's own body that is taken on is nonexistent, there is the ability to benefit and bring happiness to all sentient beings, and the meaning of one's own body that is taken on can be perceived.
There is another meaning. The World-Honored One's intention in speaking of the eight metaphors such as magical transformation will now be revealed.

The analogy of the magical creation is used to eliminate the six internal sense bases such as the eye, and one should know that it illustrates the six sense bases such as the eye, which are like magical elephants that, although actually non-existent, can be perceived.
The analogy of a mirage is used to eliminate the world of vessels, because it is vast.
In a mirage, there is actually no water, but due to the power of movement, it can be perceived as water.

The analogy of a dream is used to eliminate the objects of enjoyment such as form, and illustrates that in a dream, form and so forth are actually non-existent, but can serve as causes for the arising of pleasant and unpleasant experiences.
The analogy of a reflection is used to eliminate the results of bodily karma, and illustrates that based on good and bad bodily karma, other reflected forms arise.
The analogy of an echo is used to eliminate the results of verbal karma, and illustrates that the causes of verbal karma and the results of verbal karma are like an echo.
Mental karma is of three kinds:
1. that of the stage of non-concentration, 2. that of the stage of concentration, and 3. that of the type of hearing.

The analogy of light and shadow is used to eliminate the fruits of mental actions in the stage of non-concentration, showing that the fruits obtained by these mental actions are like light and shadow.

The analogy of the moon in the water is used to eliminate the fruits of mental actions in the stage of concentration, showing that the fruits of mental actions in the stage of concentration are like the moon in the water.

The analogy of transformation is used to eliminate the mental actions of the type of hearing. The type of hearing refers to the perfuming of hearing and contemplation. This shows that the mental actions of the type of hearing transform differently, like a transformation.
The treatise says:
Based on what hidden meaning did the World-Honored One say in the Brahma's Questions Sutra:
The Tathagata does not attain birth and death, nor does he attain nirvana.
In the dependent nature, based on the imagined nature and the perfected nature, there is the hidden meaning of the non-difference between birth and death and nirvana.
Why is it so?
This dependent nature, by the part of the imagined nature, becomes samsara, and by the part of the perfected nature, becomes nirvana.
The commentary says:
The characteristics of these three natures are in accordance with all the sutras that have been taught. This will now be shown.

The World-Honored One, based on what hidden meaning, said in the Brahma's Questions Sutra that the Tathagata does not attain samsara and does not attain nirvana? The question is: Based on the hidden meaning of the dependent nature, in terms of the imagined nature and the perfected nature, there is no distinction between samsara and nirvana. The answer will be explained in detail later.
The dependent nature is not definitely samsara, because by the part of the perfected nature it becomes nirvana;
It is also not definitely nirvana, because by the part of the imagined nature it becomes samsara. Therefore, it cannot be definitely said to be of one nature.
Because of this nature, if one part is attained, the other parts are not different.
Based on this meaning, in that sutra it is said that the Tathagata does not attain samsara and does not attain nirvana.
The treatise says:
In the Abhidharma Mahayana Sutra, the Bhagavat said that dharmas are of three kinds:
1. the defiled aspect, 2. the pure aspect, 3. the aspect of those two.
Based on what hidden meaning is this said?
Within the dependent nature, the imagined nature is the defiled aspect, and the perfected nature is the pure aspect. The dependent itself is the aspect of those two.
Based on this hidden meaning, this is said.
In this meaning, what metaphor is used to illustrate it?
Using the metaphor of a gold mine is used to show it.
It is like the world, in which three dharmas can be obtained in a gold mine:
1. the earth element, 2. soil, 3. gold.
Within the earth element, soil is not really existent but can be obtained, while gold is really existent but cannot be obtained.
When it is burned and refined by fire, the earth element does not manifest, while the gold element manifests.
Moreover, when the earth element manifests as earth, it manifests falsely, while when it manifests as gold, it manifests truly. Therefore, the earth element is composed of those two parts.

Consciousness is also like this. When it is not yet burned by the fire of nondiscriminating cognition, the false imagined nature that exists in this consciousness manifests, while the true perfected nature does not manifest.
When this consciousness is burned by the fire of nondiscriminating cognition, the true perfected nature that exists in this consciousness manifests, while the false imagined nature does not manifest.
Therefore, this consciousness of false imagination, the dependent nature, has those two parts, like the earth element in a gold and earth mixture.
The commentary says:
In the Abhidharma MahÄyÄna SÅ«tras, three dharmas are taught with this hidden meaning:
The first is the defiled part, which is the imagined nature, because it is defiled.
The second is the pure part, which is the perfected nature, because it is pure.
The third is the part that is both, which is the dependent on others nature, because it is common to both.
In order to illustrate this meaning, the example of a gold mine is used.
Here, a mine is the seeds of those two natures.
The earth element is the quality of solidity.
Earth and gold are derivative form.
In this example, three dharmas can be obtained. In this mine, the appearance of earth is manifest at first, and later the appearance of gold can be obtained.
In order to illustrate that the appearance of gold can only be obtained later, it is said that after being burned and refined by fire, it can be obtained, and therefore gold truly exists.
The treatise says:

The World-Honored One has said in some places that all dharmas are permanent, in some places that all dharmas are impermanent, and in some places that all dharmas are neither permanent nor impermanent.
On what hidden meaning does he rely to make such statements?

He relies on the fact that the nature of dependent arising is permanent due to the aspect of the perfectly accomplished nature, impermanent due to the aspect of the imagined nature, and neither permanent nor impermanent due to the two aspects.
He makes such statements based on this hidden meaning.

Just as permanence and impermanence are non-dual, so are suffering and happiness non-dual, purity and impurity non-dual, emptiness and non-emptiness non-dual, self and non-self non-dual, quiescence and non-quiescence non-dual, having intrinsic nature and lacking intrinsic nature non-dual, arising and non-arising non-dual, cessation and non-cessation non-dual, originally quiescent and not originally quiescent non-dual, naturally nirvÄá¹‡a and not naturally nirvÄá¹‡a non-dual, and saá¹ƒsÄra and nirvÄá¹‡a are also non-dual in the same way.
All such distinctions in the secret language of the buddhas should be understood according to the three natures, as explained above in terms of permanence, impermanence, and so on.
Here there are many verses:
Just as dharmas are not really existent, and just as they appear not as one kind,
Not dharma, not non-dharma, therefore the meaning of non-duality is spoken of.
Based on one part, it is either existent or non-existent,
Based on both parts, it is said to be neither existent nor non-existent.
As it appears, it is not existent, therefore it is said to be non-existent,
Because it appears like this, therefore it is said to be existent.
Naturally, its own essence is non-existent, its own nature is not firmly abiding,
As it is grasped, it does not exist, therefore it is accepted as having no self-nature.
Because of having no nature, it is accomplished, and is the basis for what follows,
Without arising or ceasing, originally quiescent, its own nature is parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The commentary says:

In the meaning of the verses, just as it is not existent, just as it appears, it is not of one kind, it explains the reason why it is neither existent nor nonexistent, because it is not existent, it is not existent; because it appears, it is not nonexistent. Because it is neither existent nor nonexistent, it is said to have the meaning of non-duality.
Based on one part means based on one side.
Revealing means explaining.
Sometimes existent, sometimes nonexistent means sometimes having the nature of existence, sometimes having the nature of nonexistence.
Based on both parts, it is said to be neither existent nor nonexistent means taking the dependent nature that has the nature of both parts, and saying it is neither existent nor nonexistent.
Just as it appears, it is not existent means that what is obtained as it appears does not exist in that way.
Therefore it is said to be nonexistent means for this reason it is said to be nonexistent.
Because it appears in this way means because it appears with the mere aspect of seeming existence.
Therefore it is said to be existent means for this very reason it is said to be existent.
The meaning of the absence of intrinsic nature of all dharmas is now about to be revealed.
The absence of natural existence is because all dharmas are devoid of a nature that exists naturally apart from conditions. This is called one kind of absence of intrinsic nature.
The absence of intrinsic nature in terms of substance is because dharmas, having ceased, do not arise again, and therefore lack intrinsic nature. This is also one kind of absence of intrinsic nature.
The absence of intrinsic nature in terms of stability of intrinsic nature is because dharmas, having just arisen, lack the power to remain for a second moment, and therefore lack intrinsic nature.
Such principles of the absence of intrinsic nature of all dharmas are shared with the Å›rÄvakas.
However, the absence of intrinsic nature that is accepted due to the non-existence of the grasped and grasper is not shared with the Å›rÄvakas.
Because the imagined nature grasped by foolish ordinary beings does not exist in that way, it is with this intention that it is said in the MahÄyÄna that all dharmas lack intrinsic nature.
Because of the absence of intrinsic nature, it is established means that because all dharmas lack intrinsic nature, non-arising, non-cessation, and so forth are all established.
Why is this so?

Because of the absence of intrinsic nature, there is no arising. Because of no arising, there is also no cessation. Because of no arising and cessation, [all things] are originally quiescent. Because of original quiescence, [all things] are naturally in a state of nirvÄá¹‡a.
The subsequent supports are the subsequent causes and conditions by which meaning can be had.
The treatise states:
There are four kinds of intentions and four kinds of secrets, all of which should be understood in the Buddha's words.
The four intentions are: First, the intention of equality, which is like saying:
I was once at that time and in that life called the Perfectly Enlightened One VipaÅ›yin.
Second, the intention of different times, which is like saying:
If one recites the name of the TathÄgata PrabhÅ«taratna, one will certainly attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
And like saying:
By merely making a vow, one can be reborn in the Land of Ultimate Bliss.
Third, the intention of different meanings, which is like saying:
If one has already encountered and served as many buddhas as the sands of the Ganges River, one will then be able to understand the meaning of the MahÄyÄna teachings.
Fourth, the intentions and inclinations of the four kinds of individuals, referring to how for one individual one first praises giving and later criticizes it.
As with giving, so it is also with precepts and a part of meditation.
These are called the four kinds of intentions.

As for the four kinds of secrets, the first is the secret of inducing entry, referring to how in the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle or the Great Vehicle, based on the conventional truth, it is said that there are individuals and the intrinsic natures and distinctions of phenomena.
The second is the secret of characteristics, referring to how in this context the characteristics of phenomena are explained, revealing the three natures.
The third is the secret of antidotes, referring to how in this context the practice of antidotes is explained, with eighty-four thousand [antidotes].
The fourth is the secret of transformation, referring to how in this context different meanings are revealed through different words and letters.
As a verse says:
Awakening to what is not solid as solid, well abiding in the inverted,
Extremely afflicted by afflictions, attaining supreme enlightenment.
The explanation says:

As for the distinction in the secret meaning of the Buddha's intention, it means that the World-Honored One first contemplates this matter and later explains it for others, which is called the intention.
By this, one is definitely caused to enter the holy teachings, which is called the secret.
The intention of equality means that it is like someone taking similar dharmas and saying such words:
That is precisely me.
The World-Honored One is also like this. The equal Dharma body is placed in the mind, and it is said:
I have already been to them.
It is not that the Buddha VipaÅ›yin of the past is precisely ÅšÄkyamuni of today. Based on the meaning of equality, the intention that arises makes such statements.
The intention of a different time means that this intention causes the lazy to diligently cultivate various causes and various dharmas, and the various wholesome roots all attain growth.

The intention here is to show that reciting the name of the TathÄgata of Abundant Treasures is a cause for advancement, not that merely reciting the name one will definitely attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
As it is said:
By one gold coin one can obtain a thousand gold coins.
How can this be done in one day?
The intention is in regard to a different time, because by one gold coin one is a cause for obtaining a thousand, therefore this is said.
This is also like this. By merely making a vow one can be reborn in the Land of Ultimate Bliss. One should know that this is also so.

Among the intentions of different meanings, those who are able to understand the meaning in the MahÄyÄna teachings are those who personally realize the characteristics of the meaning of the three kinds of natures.
If one merely understands the meaning that accords with verbal names, even fools should be able to understand this.
Therefore one should know that the meaning of understanding the meaning here is in the realization that one must have encountered and served many Buddhas in the past.
The intention of the inclinations of individuals is, for example, first praising giving and then later criticizing it for one person.
The meaning here is that first, for those who are stingy, one praises giving;
later, for those who delight in practicing giving, one again criticizes it in order to make them cultivate superior practices.
If there were no such meaning, then praising and criticizing in one giving would be contradictory.
Because there is this meaning, praising and criticizing are reasonable.
One should understand the same for morality and so forth.
Partial cultivation refers to mundane cultivation.

The secret for entering refers to where, relying on the principle of conventional truth, it is said that there are the self-natures and distinctions of individuals and all dharmas, in order to cause sentient beings to enter the Buddha's holy teachings. Therefore, it is called the secret for entering.
The secret of characteristics refers to where, in the explanations of the characteristics of dharmas, the three natures are spoken of.

The secret of antidotes refers to where, in the explanations of the antidotes to the activities of sentient beings, antidotes to the activities of the afflictions of sentient beings are spoken of in order to establish them.
As for the secret of transformation, it means that in this place, other meanings are expressed by transforming other words and letters.
As for realizing the unshakable as unshakable in the verses, the unshakable refers to concentration, because it is not firm, scattered, difficult to tame, and therefore called unshakable;
Herein, to give rise to the realization of respect is called realizing the unshakable.
As for well abiding in the inverted, it means the meaning of being able to well abide in the inverted and the able to invert.

Regarding the impermanent, etc., to consider it as permanent, etc., is called inverted. Regarding the impermanent, etc., to consider it as impermanent, etc., is the able to invert. This is the meaning of being able to well abide in this.
As for being greatly troubled by afflictions, diligent exertion is called affliction.
For the sake of sentient beings, for a long time, being troubled by diligent exertion, as it is said in the recitation:
Dwelling in birth and death for a long time, only because of great compassion.
This is so, etc.
As for attaining supreme enlightenment, its meaning is easy to understand.
The treatise says:
If one wishes to compose a commentary on the MahÄyÄna teachings, it should be done concisely by means of three aspects:
First, by explaining dependent origination; second, by explaining the characteristics of dharmas produced from conditions; third, by explaining the meaning of the words.
The commentary states:
By means of these three aspects, one should, as appropriate, compose commentaries on all MahÄyÄna teachings.
The treatise states:
Here, explaining dependent origination is as follows: It is said:
Dharmas born from the perfuming of words arise from that,
Maturation and evolving consciousnesses are mutually causes for each other.
The commentary states:

Dharmas born from the perfuming of words means that external discriminating perfuming exists in the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna. With this perfuming as the cause, all dharmas arise, which is the essence of the evolving consciousnesses.

This arises from that means that this discriminating perfuming uses those dharmas as its cause. This reveals that the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna and those evolving consciousnesses are mutually causes for each other. The treatise states:
Furthermore, the characteristics of those transforming consciousnesses are characterized by having characteristics and having views, with consciousness as their intrinsic nature.
Moreover, they are characterized by being bases, characterized by being imagined, and characterized by being the nature of dharmas. This reveals the characteristics of the three natures.
As it is said:
From that which has characteristics and has views, one should know those three characteristics.
Furthermore, how should their characteristics be explained?

It means that the characteristics of the imagined are actually non-existent within the characteristics of the dependent on others, and the characteristics of the perfected are actually existent within them.
Because of these two kinds of non-existence and existence, non-attainment and attainment, those who have not yet seen the truth and those who have already seen the truth are simultaneous.
It means that within the nature that is dependent on others, there is no imagined, and therefore there is perfected.
When transforming at this point, if one attains that, one does not attain this. If one attains this, one does not attain that.
As it is said:
The dependent and the imagined are non-existent, and the perfected exists within them,
Therefore, obtaining and not obtaining, the two in between are equal.
The commentary says:

The characteristics of those transforming consciousnesses are dharmas with characteristics and seeing consciousness as their nature. This means that those consciousnesses have characteristics and seeing as their essence.
Moreover, those characteristics have three kinds of bases as their characteristics. This means the characteristics of dependent arising.
Because these three kinds of natures that are explained show their characteristics, in the verses they reveal this meaning.
From with characteristics and seeing up to one should know their three characteristics, as explained.

Because of these two kinds, which are non-existent and existent, not obtaining and obtaining, those who have not yet seen and those who have already seen the truth simultaneously, the imagined and the perfected are called the two kinds.
These two kinds are the first non-existent and the second existent.
Those who have not yet seen the truth obtain the imagined and do not obtain the perfected.
Those who have already seen reality immediately attain the perfected nature, but do not attain the imagined nature.
In the verse, this meaning is revealed, namely, the other-dependent and the imagined do not exist, but the perfected exists.
Equal means one moment.
Among means among the other-dependent.
Two refers to those who have not yet seen reality and those who have already seen reality.
Therefore means by this cause.
It means that among the other-dependent, because the imagined does not exist, and because the perfected exists.
Moreover, because foolish worldlings have inverted attachments, their views arise in this way.
If noble ones, due to right views, their views arise in this way.
The treatise says:

The one who explains the meaning of the words first states the initial phrase, and then uses the remaining phrases to analyze and reveal it, either by means of the qualities or by means of the meaning.
The commentary says:
By explaining the meaning of the words as they were created, we will now reveal whether they encompass its virtues or its meaning.
The treatise states:
As for the aspect of virtues, it refers to explaining the Buddha's merits:
The purest enlightenment, the non-dual practice, the approach to the Dharma of signlessness, abiding in the Buddha's abode,
Attaining the equality of all Buddhas, reaching the unobstructed realm, the irreversible Dharma,
The unobstructed practice, the inconceivable establishment, wandering in the equality of the Dharma nature of the three times,
His body pervading all worlds, with wisdom in all dharmas free from doubt or hesitation,
In all practices he achieves great enlightenment, with the wisdom of all dharmas free from confusion or doubt, whatever
Body he manifests is beyond discrimination, the wisdom sought by all bodhisattvas, attaining the non-dual Buddha
Abiding on the other shore, unmixed, the TathÄgata's liberation and wondrous wisdom are ultimate, realizing the absence of
The middle, the extremes, the Buddha ground are equal, extending to the Dharma realm, exhausting the nature of empty space, reaching the end of the future
limit, the most pure enlightenment.
One should know that this phrase is distinguished and explained by the remaining phrases, and in this way it becomes well-spoken.

The most pure enlightenment of the Dharma nature refers to the most pure enlightenment of the World-Honored Buddha. It should be known as being included in the twenty-one kinds of merits of the Buddha.

Namely, the merit of turning without obstruction in the knowable, the merit of supreme pure entry into the suchness of the non-dual characteristic of existence and non-existence, the merit of abiding without rest in effortless buddha-work,

the merit of the absence of difference in support, intention, and activity in the Dharma body, the merit of cultivating the antidotes to all hindrances, the merit of subduing all non-Buddhists, the merit of being born in the world without being
obstructed by worldly dharmas, the merit of establishing the true Dharma, the merit of giving predictions,
The merit of manifesting the enjoyment and transformation bodies in all worlds, the merit of severing doubts,

the merit of causing entry into various practices, the merit of the marvelous cognition of the arising of future dharmas, the merit of manifesting according to one's understanding, the merit of the immeasurable practices of subduing sentient beings based on various supports,

the merit of perfecting the pÄramitÄs of the equal Dharma body, the merit of manifesting the distinctions of buddha lands according to one's understanding, the merit of the three buddha bodies having no spatial limitations, the merit of always benefiting and bringing peace and happiness to all sentient beings until the end of saá¹ƒsÄra, the merit of inexhaustibility, and so forth.
The commentary says:
Here, non-dual activity means that the two activities are non-existent here, and therefore it is called non-dual activity.
This is the merit of unimpeded activity with regard to all objects of cognition, unlike the cognition of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, which is both impeded and unimpeded.

Approaching the Dharma of signlessness refers to pure suchness, which is called the Dharma of signlessness. Approaching means entering. It is the supreme purity of entering into suchness, which is neither existent nor nonexistent.
This suchness is not characterized by existence, because dharmas are without essence as their characteristic.
It is also not characterized by nonexistence, because its own characteristic exists.
In this supreme purity of suchness without characteristics, one is able to enter. Because it is supreme, one is able to enter; because it is pure, one is able to enter.

Abiding in the Buddha's abode refers to abiding in the Buddha's abode, which is the abode of nonabiding. This is the merit of abiding without effort in the Buddha's work without rest. It means that in this abiding, one always performs the Buddha's work without rest.
Attaining the equality of all Buddhas refers to the merit of the absence of distinction in the basis, intention, and activity within the Dharma body.
Arriving at the place without obstruction refers to the merit of cultivating the antidotes to all obstructions, that is, always cultivating the wisdom of enlightenment to counteract all obstructions.
The Dharma that cannot be turned back refers to the merit of subduing all non-Buddhists.

Unimpeded in practice refers to the merit of being born in the world without being obstructed by worldly dharmas, that is, although born in the world and practicing in the places practiced by worldly people, one is not defiled by the eight worldly dharmas such as profit.

The established is inconceivable refers to the merit of establishing the true Dharma, because the true Dharma such as the sutras is immeasurable and inconceivable, and cannot be understood by ordinary foolish people.
For this reason, it is called the purest enlightenment. This phrase of the purest enlightenment is universally applicable in every phrase.
Roaming in the nature of dharmas that is equal throughout the three times refers to the merit of giving predictions.
His body pervades all worlds means the merit of manifesting the enjoyment and transformation bodies in all worlds.
His wisdom in all dharmas is free from doubt means the merit of eliminating doubt.
He has attained great enlightenment in all practices means the merit of causing entry into various practices.

His wisdom in all dharmas is free from doubt means the merit of the marvelous wisdom of the arising of future dharmas, which is to say, knowing the marvelous wisdom of the TathÄgata of the arising of such future dharmas.
Any body he manifests is beyond discrimination means the merit of manifesting according to one's resolve.

The wisdom sought by all bodhisattvas means the merit of the immeasurable activities of taming sentient beings, which is to say, the immeasurable bodhisattvas rely on it to carry out the work of taming sentient beings. This is not that the Buddhas, having already attained the equality of self and others, seek this wisdom again. Only the Buddhas have already accomplished such supreme taming activities.
Attaining the Buddha's non-duality and abiding in the supreme other shore refers to the merit of perfecting the pÄramitÄ of the equal Dharma body.
The non-dual Dharma body is called the equal Dharma body. One attains the well-purified pÄramitÄ in this non-dual Dharma body.
The TathÄgata's liberation and wondrous cognition, ultimately without being mixed together means that in the TathÄgata's cognition, which is not mixed together, one's understanding is ultimate.
Here, understanding is called liberation, which is the merit of manifesting distinctions according to one's understanding.

Realizing the equality of the Buddha's ground, without middle or edge refers to the merit of the three kinds of Buddha bodies having no spatial limitations. The Dharma body of the Buddha cannot be limited to a certain space, and the enjoyment and transformation bodies also cannot be said to be in a certain world.

Extending to the Dharma realm means extending to the perfectly pure Dharma realm. This is called extending to the Dharma realm, which is the merit of always benefiting and bringing peace and happiness to all sentient beings until the end of saá¹ƒsÄra.
The nature of empty space refers to inexhaustible merit, meaning that the Buddha's wisdom is inexhaustible like empty space.
Extending to the end of the future refers to ultimate merit.
The word equal means that this Buddha's wisdom is equal to the ultimate extension to the end of the future without interruption. Therefore, it is called the purest enlightenment.
The treatise says:

Furthermore, in terms of the realm of meaning, it is said that if bodhisattvas accomplish thirty-two dharmas, they are called bodhisattvas. Namely, because they give rise to the superior intention of benefiting and bringing peace to all sentient beings,
They cause them to enter the wisdom of omniscience, because they know for themselves what kind of wisdom they have now, because they subdue arrogance,
Because they have a firm superior intention, because they are not falsely compassionate, because they have an impartial mind towards friends and non-friends,
Because they forever become good friends until the end of nirvana, because they speak in moderation,
Because they smile first when speaking, because they have unlimited great compassion, because they have no attachment to what they receive,

Because of being weak, having no intention of being weary, being insatiable in hearing the Dharma, deeply seeing faults in one's own transgressions,ğŸ”½not being angry but instructing in the transgressions of others, always cultivating the mind of enlightenment in all deportments,
not hoping for karmic retribution but practicing generosity, not relying on
any destinies while upholding precepts, being free from anger and obstruction towards sentient beings while practicing patience,
striving diligently in order to embrace all wholesome dharmas, abandoning the formless realm and cultivating meditative concentration,
cultivating wisdom in union with skillful means, embracing with the four means of gathering disciples and skillful means,
not discriminating between good and bad friends in terms of precepts and transgressions, listening to the true Dharma with a sincere mind,
dwelling in the forest with a sincere mind, not delighting in worldly affairs,
never delighting in the inferior vehicle, deeply seeing the merits in the Great Vehicle,
Therefore, because of avoiding bad friends, because of associating with good friends, because of always cultivating the four kinds of Brahma abodes

, because of always playing with the five supernatural powers, because of relying on wisdom, because of not abandoning those sentient beings who abide in right practice and those who do not abide in right practice, because of definite speech, because of valuing the truth
, because of always taking the mind of great enlightenment as the foremost,
these phrases should be known as all being distinctions of the first phrase, namely, the superior intention to benefit and bring happiness to all sentient beings.
This phrase of the superior intention to benefit and bring happiness has sixteen kinds of distinctions in its activities, which should be known.
Here, the sixteen kinds of activities are: 1. The activity of successive practice;
2. The activity of non-perversion;
3. The activity of spontaneous practice without waiting for others' requests;
4. The activity of imperturbability and indestructibility;

The fifth is the action of being free from the defilement of seeking, which should be understood as having three distinctions, namely, being free from the bonds of defilement, being without attachment and aversion towards kindness and harm, and always continuing from birth to birth.
The sixth is the action of speech and body that is in accord with the Dharma, which should be understood as having two distinctions.
The seventh is the action of being impartial towards pleasure, pain, and neither, the eighth is the action of being without inferiority,
the ninth is the action of being without regression,
the tenth is the action of embracing skillful means,
the eleventh is the action of detesting what is to be countered, which should be understood as having two distinctions,
the twelfth is the action of uninterrupted attention,

the thirteenth is the action of superior practice, which should be understood as having seven distinctions, namely, the correct practice of the six perfections and the four means of gathering [disciples],

The fourteenth is the perfection of preparatory practice, which should be known to have six distinctions, namely, because of associating with good people, listening to the true Dharma, dwelling in seclusion, abandoning evil thoughts, and the merit of attention, which should be known to have two distinctions, namely, because of companions and merit, which should be known to have two distinctions;
The fifteenth is the perfection of practice, which should be known to have three distinctions, namely, because of immeasurable purity, attaining great power, and realizing merit;

The sixteenth is the establishment of their practice, which should be known to have four distinctions, namely, because of the merit of leading the assembly, because of definitive and doubt-free instruction and admonition, because of attracting with both material and Dharma, and because of an undistracted mind.
One should know that all these phrases are distinctions of the first phrase.
The commentary says:

Because of the middle of the meaning, the superior intention of benefit and happiness is generated towards all sentient beings. This sentence meaning is shown by the remaining sentences of the sixteen activities.
By what activities is the superior intention of benefit and happiness shown?

Namely, the activity of mutual practice is precisely in order to cause entry into omniscience. That is to say, in order to cause all sentient beings to enter omniscience, they are mutually transformed and guided, just as one lamp transmits a thousand lamps. This precisely shows the superior intention of benefit and happiness.
In this way, all the remaining sentences should be matched with the superior intention of benefit and happiness.
The activity without perversion is precisely because one knows for oneself, What kind of expedient wisdom do I have now?

That is to say, even if there is a superior intention of benefit and happiness, it is still perverted, just as there is the generation of a superior intention of benefit and happiness in encouraging drinking alcohol, etc.
If one has right wisdom and truly knows oneself, one can then weigh and teach sentient beings, not with the conceit of not truly knowing and encouraging others to do what is harmful.

The one who naturally engages without waiting for others to request is precisely the one who subdues conceit. That is to say, because one subdues the mind of arrogance, one teaches the Dharma without waiting for requests.

The one whose activity is unshakable and indestructible is precisely the one with a firm superior intention. That is to say, because sentient beings engage in wrong practices, one does not move or destroy the firm mind of superior intention to benefit and bring peace.

The one whose activity is free from seeking and defilement is precisely the one who is not hypocritical in compassion, because one has an impartial mind towards friends and non-friends, and because one always acts as a good friend until the end of nirvana.

That is to say, the last three phrases explain these three phrases. It is not for the sake of gain, respect, etc., that one acts to benefit and bring peace to sentient beings. Therefore, it is said that the superior intention to benefit and bring peace is free from seeking and defilement.
How can this be known?
It is said that the characteristics of speech and physical action are in accord with the Dharma, because one speaks in a timely manner and greets with a smile.
In these two phrases, speaking in a timely manner and greeting with a smile are verbal actions, and smiling is physical action.
Speaking in a timely manner means only speaking the Dharma.
Smiling means with a cheerful countenance coming and going to do beneficial things.

As for the phrase equal action in regard to happiness, suffering, and the absence of both, it means immeasurable great compassion, because immeasurable compassion means pitying the three kinds of suffering. In regard to sentient beings who are suffering, one pities their suffering of suffering; in regard to sentient beings who are happy, one pities their suffering of change; in regard to sentient beings who are neither suffering nor happy, one pities their suffering of the karmic formations. Neither suffering nor happy is called the absence of both.
As for the phrase action that is not inferior, it means not being weak in what one has accepted, that is, not belittling oneself by saying I cannot attain Buddhahood and so forth.
The action of non-retrogression is precisely the mind of non-weariness, that is, diligently cultivating the causes of Buddhahood without weariness.
The action of embracing skillful means is precisely the absence of weariness in hearing the meaning, that is, by much hearing one accomplishes skillful wisdom and benefits sentient beings.

The action of despising the objects of abandonment is precisely deeply seeing the faults in one's own transgressions and not being angry at others' transgressions but instructing them, by which expedient one is able to truly subdue sentient beings.
The action of uninterrupted attention is precisely always cultivating the mind of enlightenment in all deportments.
The meaning of these phrases is as extensively explained in the sutras on pure practice.
The action of superior practice is precisely practicing giving without hoping for retribution, up to embracing skillful means by the four means of gathering disciples.
That is to say, relying on the superior intention of benefit and bliss, one cultivates these practices as the cause for increasing and heading towards the fruition.

The action of perfecting the practice is precisely because there is no distinction between those who uphold precepts and those who violate precepts, up to and including being a good friend and closely following a good friend.
That is to say, the latter six phrases explain these eight phrases.
If one practices in this way, one will quickly perfect [the practice].
Because one dwells in the forest with a sincere mind, one is free from evil thoughts by dwelling in this place.
Worldly affairs refers to singing, dancing, and so forth.
The action of perfection is precisely because one always cultivates the four immeasurables, always plays with the five supernatural powers, and relies on wisdom.
That is to say, the latter three phrases explain these three phrases, which are the characteristics of this perfected action.
Great power refers to the six supernatural powers.
Because one relies on wisdom, one does not rely on consciousness. Because inner wisdom arises, by means of this inner wisdom one directly sees and abides in the Dharma.
The action of establishing them is precisely abiding in correct practice and so forth.
The last four sentences explain these four sentences.
Because of the superior intention of benefiting and bringing happiness, one establishes sentient beings in benefit and happiness.

As for the merit of leading the assembly, even towards those who violate precepts one does not abandon them, establishes them without expulsion, causes them to leave unwholesomeness and abide in wholesomeness.

As for the definitive and doubt-free teaching and admonishment, because one is able to unilaterally give them instructions, not saying after one's own statement, My words are unwholesome, due to this cause and condition their words are awe-inspiring.
As for the unity of attracting through wealth and Dharma, because of the truthfulness of words, one attracts robes and other wealth, and then gives them in the same way.
As for the mind free from defilement, because of well-embracing the mind of great enlightenment and benefiting sentient beings, not seeking to be served by oneself.
How do sentient beings quickly realize unsurpassed perfect enlightenment due to this good?
Thus all sentient beings are embraced.

Because of the initial phrase, the different virtues of the phrase;
Because of the initial phrase, the distinctions in meaning of the phrase.
